text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with smoked trout schmear that's
right I've been wanting to feature this
delicious product in a video for a very
long time and I was hoping to use it in
something very different very creative
but then I came to my senses and
realized I really need to show you what
I think is the ultimate smoked trout
delivery system the schmear if you are
wondering what the difference is between
a schmear and a spread mostly the
spelling but personally I think schmear
looks way cooler plus nobody can argue
it's way more fun to say
Shamir but anyway no matter what you
call this the first step to make it is
going to be the same we need to make
sure we have some room temperature cream
cheese so what we'll do is we'll toss
our cream cheese in a bowl a few hours
before we're going to make this and
leave it out at room temp until it's
very soft and pliable ensure you can
make this with cold cream cheese it's
just going to be a little harder and who
needs the extra work so we're going to
make sure we have some nice soft cream
cheese to work with before we move on to
the star of the show the smoked trout
check it out
so I have two boneless skinless fillets
here those are going to be about two to
three ounces each and the color can vary
from what you see here to a bright
orange rad that looks almost exactly
like smoked salmon so there are many
different varieties of trout but as long
as it's smoked it will work here and
what we're going to want to do before we
proceed is to break this up into little
pieces and we're doing this for a couple
of reasons
it's going to mix into our cream cheese
a lot easier but more importantly even
though this is sold as boneless you may
and probably will still find a couple
small bones in there and by the way let
me show you a better system then just
randomly breaking this stuff up what we
really want to do is push everything to
one side so we can systematically
crumble everything into a pile which is
going to make it a lot easier to see
what's going on and less chance we're
going to miss one of those little bones
in case you're keeping score at home I
found exactly two and then once our
smoked trout fillets have been broken up
let's go ahead and dump that into our
bowl of cream cheese and proceed with
the rest of the ingredients the first of
which would be a spoon of capers and
quite often for recipes like this they
call for the capers to be chopped but I
don't like that
I like to put them in whole because as
we mix this with our fork those will get
broken up a little bit which is going to
release all those beautiful briny
flavors but it's not going to be quite
as intense as if we mince these up so
we're going
toss in some whole capers followed by a
spoon of hot prepared horseradish which
of course you can get at the store or I
just saw an amazing video for how to
make that yourself which of course we're
going to provide a link for and then
we're also going to season this up with
a little bit of freshly ground black
pepper as well as a little bit of salt
but not too much because usually smoked
fish is kind of salty and of course
we'll check and adjust for that later
and then let's also give this a little
shake of cayenne because it's good and
good for you and then to balance the
creaminess of the cheese and the
richness of that smoked trout we're
going to want a little bit of acidity
which in this case will be provided by
freshly squeezed lemon juice and then
we're going to finish this off with some
freshly chopped herbs so we'll do a
little bit of chive which is going to
give us a little touch of that onion
flavor without being overpowering a lot
of people like to use a little bit of
minced Ronning in this but for me that's
just a little too harsh and then we'll
finish this off with some chopped dill
also known as the ultimate smoked fish
herb so for whatever reason I'm sure
it's all very scientific fresh dill just
pairs perfectly with any kind of smoked
fish I'm sure someone will explain it to
me in the comments section and once all
that's in there we can go ahead and fork
elate this until it reaches what we
would personally consider the perfect
texture so I'm going to mix this up with
the fork kind of using the back of it to
smash stuff against the bottom of the
bowl and as I mentioned earlier that's
going to kind of break up those capers
as well as hopefully mix everything
together and if you want you can just
mix it a little bit and leave it coarse
like this or as they call it in the
business rustic or as I prefer you could
continue mixing until you have something
much smoother and by the way I joked
earlier about the difference between a
smear and a spread and there really
isn't any but what is very different is
a mousse all right some people like to
put this kind of thing in a mixer and
whip a lot of air into it which I don't
like at all it's too light in fact some
of your delis will whip in as much as
50% air into this which means basically
you're paying like $18 a pound for air
which is not a good deal but anyway
we'll continue mixing until we think
it's perfect at which point you're
probably going to want to taste it which
is fine by all means give it a taste
but I don't think we want to make our
final decisions on seasoning just yet
because what I like to do is transfer
this into the fridge for a couple hours
to let it chill thoroughly and to give
it time for those flavors to fully
mingle and mature
so I transferred mine into a ramekin and
we'll wrap that in plastic and if you
want these people that have emailed me
asking why I always press the plastic
down onto the product well if you think
about it the reason we wrap something is
to keep the air away from it and by
pressing that plastic down we've
actually eliminated any air so that's
the official reason but anyway I'm going
to wrap that up and pop it in the fridge
I'm going to put it right next to that
head of lettuce that still has the root
attached what you think would be cheaper
since I have to do all the work but no
it's more expensive and like I said
we're going to let that sit in the
fridge for a couple hours let those
flavors develop after which we'll pull
it out and give it the official taste
for seasoning and of course deciding
what you need to add if anything is
going to be up to you you are the
premier of your smoked trout schmear so
you'll have to determine if it need some
more salt or some more lemon or some
more heat or whatever but I am happy to
report mine was perfect so I moved on to
my favorite step the presenting and
eating of the schmear so I'm gonna go
ahead and serve that up alongside some
pumpernickel and some radishes and by
the way I couldn't afford the fancy
French breakfast radishes that have that
beautiful white bang going around them
so instead I just carved around some
regular cheap red radishes which will
fool nobody but regardless let's go in
for our official taste and if you
haven't had it before this stuff is just
incredible and like most normal people I
love smoked salmon spread or schmear but
I gotta tell you I think smoked trout is
superior it just has such a gorgeous
slightly sweet beautifully rich flavor
which is why if you noticed we were a
little bit restrained and what we added
to this okay we really don't want to
overpower cover up that amazing flavor
just an incredibly delicious substance
to spread on pretty much anything in
fact in hindsight my only regret here is
not showing you this finished on top of
a toasted bagel which is just beyond
perfection and know when it comes to
food that is not impossible so I really
do hope you give this a try soon head
over to food wishes comm for all the
ingredient amounts and more fo as usual
and as always enjoy
you
